questions.question_text:
At a project meeting, a business analyst requires input from a marketing consultant to continue working on a task. The business analyst has tried to contact the consultant but has been told that the consultant does not have the time to discuss the project.
What should the project manager do to move the project forward?

discussion.content:
A 
In this scenario, the business analyst is unable to proceed with their work because the marketing consultant, a key resource, is unavailable to provide the necessary input. Since the consultant is not dedicating the required time to the project, the project manager should escalate this issue to the consultant’s functional manager. The functional manager is responsible for allocating the consultant’s time and can help resolve the issue by prioritizing the consultant’s involvement in the project.
A is not correct from the 'mindset' perspective. Correct answer is C.

discussion.content: Could it be A? Since it is the first planning meeting and the question is asking what the PM should do first. Proposing a MVP can be part of the contingency plan.

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D. Ask the team to propose a minimum viable product (MVP) to meet the date.

When faced with a project that has too many requirements to meet the deadline, the project manager's first step should be to ask the team to propose a minimum viable product (MVP) to meet the deadline. The MVP is the minimum set of features that will deliver value to the customer and can be delivered within the given timeframe. The team should focus on delivering the core functionality of the product, leaving non-essential features for later releases.

Ask the team to propose a minimum viable product (MVP) to meet the date. By focusing on delivering an MVP, the team can prioritize the most critical features that provide value to the customer while ensuring the project stays on track. This approach allows for a functional product by the deadline and can be expanded upon in future iterations. It’s a smart way to balance quality and timelines effectively.

questions.question_text:
A company is starting a critical project with a strict deadline. During the first planning meeting, the team realizes that the list of requirements has too many items to allow on-time delivery.
What should the project manager do first?

choices.C: Increase the active engagement and participation of key stakeholders.
choices.B: Schedule a regular risk review with the project management team.
choices.A: Update the project management plan to reduce the possibility of scope creep.
choices.D: Create a project change roadmap to keep track of all unforeseen changes.

questions.question_text:

What strategy should the project manager use to ensure a successful project completion?

discussion.content: PMI Practice Guide: Stakeholder Engagement also emphasizes the importance of engaging and involving key stakeholders in the project, particularly in complex projects. Effective stakeholder engagement can help the project manager to gain support for the project, identify and address concerns and issues, and ensure that the project meets the stakeholders' needs and expectations.

D. Planned how the delivered product will be supported after its delivery.

To prevent such a situation, the project manager should have proactively planned for post-delivery support and addressed it in the project management plan. This plan should include how defects or issues identified after the project's completion will be handled, including any costs associated with addressing them. It's essential to set clear expectations with the client regarding post-delivery support, including whether there will be a warranty period during which defects will be fixed free of charge and what happens after that period. This way, there is a mutual understanding between the project manager and the client, reducing the potential for disputes over post-delivery defect fixes.

questions.question_text:
A project manager is leading a hybrid project funded by a time and materials (T&M) agreement. The project was completed, and the client accepted the delivery of the product. One week later, the client asked the project manager to fix two defects they found in the product. The project manager responded with an estimate of time and money and asked the client to confirm this. The client disagreed and insisted that the work should be done for free because it is a defect in the product.
What should the project manager have done to prevent this?

choices.B: Reviewed the project quality control plan with the client.
choices.D: Planned how the delivered product will be supported after its delivery.
choices.C: Suggested a fixed-cost basis and included free bug fixes for 1 month.
choices.A: Trained client engineers to support the product after its delivery.
